ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Pegasus Foods management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Pegasus Foods' safety and environmental policies are administered by the Plant Engineer and General Manager, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/RMP Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Pegasus Foods facility is located at 1635 Innovation Drive, Rockwall, Texas.  The facility is located approximately 0.37 miles to the southeast of US Highway 30.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of light commercial and industrial areas. The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia. The facility uses approximately 16,000 pounds of ammonia as a refrigerant within a closed system. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the processing and cold storage of frozen food products. Typical operating conditions range from 8.8" Hg on the low pressure side of the system to 181 psig on the high side.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Pegasus Foods ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. The facility conducts preventative maintenance and any necessary minor repairs in house, but an outside contractor is h

ired for major repairs or maintenance. The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code applicable at the time of construction, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room. In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room (High Pressure Receiver and Condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves. All of the relief valves are tied into a common relief header that vent to the atmosphere.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Pegasus Foods facility is under construction and will be completed at the end of February 2018, thus there is no accident history to report.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Pegasus Foods facility has an emergency response plan in effect. The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.

2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.) To protect the environment.

4.) To minimize property damage.

The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations. In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and activate the facility's response plan to respond to the situation. If necessary, they will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans

to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analysis, conducted on October 23-24, 2017, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Pegasus Foods facility. The Pegasus Foods safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
